parameter 1: The version shown in Swedish cinemas in 1996 removed 43 meters of footage (the vice torture and baseball beatings).
parameter 2: Finnish VHS release is cut by 1 minute. Notable cuts were: - Tony Dogs being tortured with the vice - Baseball bat killings
parameter 3: At the time of release, the film was banned in Germany because the story was considered to be anti-Nazi propaganda by the wartime censors. After the end of World War II, the picture was finally released in Germany but with around 20 minutes of footage cut (all scenes with Major Strasser and all references to Nazism). Other scenes were dubbed so that they had a totally different meaning (Victor Laszlo became Victor Larsen, an atomic physicist). In the 70s the film was redubbed by the ZDF, this time in its uncut form.
parameter 4: The initial US television broadcast had the nude scenes edited out. The unedited version aired in Europe and is available in the US as an unrated video.
parameter 5: A colorized version was shown on Australian TV and was released on VHS in the United States.
parameter 6: In 2007, Kino International Corp. copyrighted a 20-second surviving fragment of the film, with a new piano music score composed and performed by 'Ben Model' (qv).
parameter 7: The initial US television broadcast had the nude scenes edited out. The unedited version aired in Europe and is available in the US as an unrated video.

parameter 9: In the Italian version, the sequence where the Italian Officer Tonnelli meets Strasser is cut.
parameter 10: Some TV versions cut the scene where Jerry's face is made black with the smoke of a cigar and is forced to dance by Tom holding a lighter under the plate he stands on.
parameter 11: The 1995 UK MIA video featured a pre-edited print which then suffered a further 3 mins 34 secs of BBFC cuts to edit whipping and torture scenes and a hinted bestiality sequence between a woman and a dog.
